qas.question: Why can't Mexico City become a state?

answers.text: Because of a clause in the Mexican Constitution

context: After years of demanding greater political autonomy, residents were given the right to directly elect a Head of Government and the representatives of the unicameral Legislative Assembly by <a4_0>popular vote<a4_0/> in <a1_0>1997<a1_0/>. Ever since, the left-wing <a2_0>Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD)<a2_0/> has controlled both of them. In recent years, the local government has passed a wave of liberal policies, such as abortion on request, a limited form of euthanasia, no-fault divorce, and same-sex marriage. On January 29, 2016, it ceased to be called the <a3_0>Federal District<a3_0/> (Spanish: Distrito Federal or D.F.) and is now in transition to become the country's 32nd federal entity, giving it a level of autonomy comparable to that of a state. <a0_0>Because of a clause in the Mexican Constitution<a0_0/>, however, as the seat of the powers of the Union, it can never become a state, lest the capital of the country be relocated elsewhere.
